'''''Panaeolus semiovatus'' var. ''semiovatus''''', also known as ''Panaeolus semiovatus'' and ''Anellaria separata'', is a medium-sized buff-colored [[mushroom]]/toadstool that [[Coprophilous fungi|grows on horse dung]], and has black spores.  While some guides list this species as [[edible mushroom|edible]], a few people experience gastric upset after consumption. Its common names are the '''shiny mottlegill''', or '''egghead mottlegill'''.

==Description==
The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is up to 8 cm across, dark buff to white, parabolic to nearly convex in maturity. It is sticky when wet, and often wrinkles when dry.  The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is 15 cm by 20 mm, solid and smooth, with an annulus (ring) that is white, but is often found blackened by falling spores. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are [[wikt:adnexed|adnexed]], being wider in the middle, and narrowing at both ends, they are brown to black. The flesh is white, or straw-colored.<ref name=Phillips06>{{Cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006  | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6}}</ref><ref name=T.Laessoe>{{Cite book | author = Thomas Laessoe | year = 1998 | title = Mushrooms (flexi bound) | publisher = Dorling Kindersley | isbn = 0-7513-1070-0}}</ref>

This is a buff, or whitish-colored mushroom that grows in horse dung. It is widely distributed and is present in many [[temperate zones]] of the world.

The very similar ''[[Panaeolus semiovatus var. phalaenarum]]'' ([[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) Ew. Gerhardt. 1996 '''syn.''' ''Panaeolus phalaenarum'' (Bull.) Quel. is more slender (cap 2–4 cm), and lacks the ring.<ref name = "MarcelBon87">{{Cite book | author = Marcel Bon | year = 1987 | title = The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe | publisher = Hodder and Stoughton | isbn = 0-340-39935-X}}</ref>

:As seen below, this mushroom varies from white to dark buff in coloration.
